awd_titl_txt: RUI: Linear trimers of Fe, Co, and Ni with unique structural, magnetic, and electrochemical properties
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is funded by the Chemical Synthesis Program in the NSF Chemistry Division. Dr. Gary Guillet of Georgia Southern University's Armstrong Campus investigates strategies to synthesize compounds containing three metal ions and two metal-metal bonds with the atoms and bonds arranged linearly. The study of metal-metal bonding is an area of intense research because of the unique properties of compounds that contain this type of bond. While there are many examples of compounds that contain two metal ions with a metal-metal bond between them, there is a dearth of compounds containing a larger number of metals with metal-metal bonding. Even more rare are compounds with metal-metal bonds that are linked in series. Dr. Guillet investigates the factors that affect the strength of the bonding, and the physical properties and reactivity of the compounds. This adds significantly to the understanding of metal-metal bonding within multi-metallic compounds and impacts fields such as molecular wire design. The student body of the Armstrong campus is diverse group and many students are minorities underrepresented in the chemical sciences. About 37% of the chemistry and biochemistry majors are first generation college students. In order to close the education gap in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics, it is critical to expand access to research experiences for students. Institutional data clearly shows that students graduate faster if they participate in undergraduate research compared to their peers. With funding from this grant, Dr. Guillet is mentoring and promoting these students.

Dimetallic complexes of transition metals are abundant and thoroughly studied. However, extending these compounds by addition of a third metal forming linear, trimetallic, complexes is synthetically challenging and there is a dearth of these complexes. Most examples that exist of trimetallic complexes are supported using the ligand dipyridylamine. Novel trimetallic complexes are required to study the properties of these extended systems and new ligands are needed for this purpose. Dr. Guillet is investigating the synthesis of a novel ligand family designed to support trimetallic complexes of Fe, Co, and Ni. The physical properties of these complexes are being examined using multinuclear NMR, X-ray diffractometry, UV-Vis spectroscopy, and IR spectroscopy. Dr. Guillet is also investigating the reactivity using electrochemistry as well as synthetic redox reactions. Work on this project is expanding the understanding of ligand characteristics necessary to support trimetallic complexes and elucidate the characteristics of metal-metal communication.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This work sought to synthesize novel molecules that contained linear chains of three metal ions.  Molecules containing chains of this type are referred to as Extended Metal Atom Chain compounds or EMACs.  The specific metals of choice used here for EMAC synthesis were iron (Fe) and cobalt (Co) and it was desired that the metals in the EMACs would reside close enough in the compound to form chemical bonds between the metals.  The reason for this is that when metal ions are in close proximity, like when they are at bonding distances, their properties will often couple together in unpredictable ways.  Specifically, the metals iron and cobalt were utilized as ions with +2 charges.  These were chosen because they are known to frequently contain unpaired electrons on each individual ion in their compounds.  Unpaired electrons on an atom leads to magnetic field existing around that atom.  The reader will know that typical magnets, when in close proximity, will either attract or repel one another.  Atoms with unpaired electrons are also magnets, but on the atomic scale, and they will also interact with one another but sometimes in unpredictable ways.

The desired outcomes of this project were to make new versions of these trimetallic EMACs with Fe and Co that were clearly different from previously synthesized trimetallic EMACs.  Then, upon successful synthesis of new EMACs, to determine their structures and measure their properties.  Success was achieved in making three novel trimetallic EMACs, two with iron and another with cobalt.  The two EMACs with iron represent the only known examples of trimetallic EMACs using iron that also have short iron-iron bonds.  All three compounds had very similar structures, and critically, the structures were very different than previously synthesized EMACs.  The magnetic properties of these new molecules were investigated and found to also be unique amongst EMACs.  The Fe and Co compounds made here had large magnetic fields, important considering that previously formed EMACs have been found to have little to no measurable magnetism. 

Another aspect of this project looked at the changes that would occur to the structure of the newly formed EMACs of Fe with the addition or subtraction of electrons.  There was interest into how the structure of a triiron chain would change with this alteration.  To this end the first ever trimetallic EMAC of Fe that had an added electron, also referred to as a reduced trimetallic EMAC of Fe, was isolated and investigated.  Upon reduction changes occurred in the iron to iron bonds and there were changes to the magnetic properties.  Versions of the trimetallic EMAC of Fe with electrons removed, or an oxidized version, could not be isolated.

The broader impact goals of this project were to incorporate a broad swatch of undergraduate students including those who are from groups underrepresented in the STEM fields.  Over the award timeline 13 undergraduate students participated in this research.  Of those 13 students ~70% were female and ~15% were minorities underrepresented in the sciences.  All participating students have graduated from Georgia Southern University or another institution, or they are on pace to graduate.  This is a key outcome as the 6-year graduation rate of Georgia Southern University is approximately 50%.  Another key outcome is increasing the exposure of participating students to the broader chemical community.  In this regard a manuscript was published on this work with a student as a co-author.  These students gave a total of 6 poster presentations at regional chemistry conferences and 4 poster presentations at national chemistry conferences.

 


Last Modified: 11/30/2022
Modified by: Gary Guillet

Image
  • Figure of the three newly synthesized EMACs in this work.
    Gary L. Guillet
    Creative Commons
    Gary Guillet
    Synthesized EMACs

Molecules containing chains of this type are referred to as Extended Metal Atom Chain compounds or EMACs.  The specific metals of choice used here for EMAC synthesis were iron (Fe) and cobalt (Co) and it was desired that the metals in the EMACs would reside close enough in the compound to form chemical bonds between the metals. Unpaired electrons on an atom leads to magnetic field existing around that atom.  The reader will know that typical magnets, when in close proximity, will either attract or repel one another.
